## Ray Bradbury Biography and McCarthyism Connection

Ray Bradbury was born on August 22, 1920, in Waukegan, Illinois, to Esther (née Moberg) Bradbury (1888–1966), a Swedish immigrant, and Leonard Spaulding Bradbury (1890–1957), a power and telephone lineman of English ancestry. He died June 5, 2012, in Los Angeles, California.

### Impact of McCarthyism on Bradbury

The rise of Senator Joseph McCarthy's McCarthyism persecution of accused communists, beginning in 1950, deepened Bradbury's contempt for government overreach. Bradbury himself was investigated by the FBI beginning in 1950, and Bradbury himself was investigated for Communist ties throughout the 1950s.

Though a Stevenson Democrat in 1952, Bradbury found himself, again, disillusioned with the presidential candidate, especially after Stevenson refused to address directly either the Korean War or Joseph McCarthy's scandalous witch hunts. Famously (or infamously, depending on one's point of view), Bradbury took out a large ad in Variety, "To the Republican Party," challenging them to disown McCarthyism as well as refrain from claiming that anyone in the Democratic Party was a Communist.

### Book Burning and Fahrenheit 451

Bradbury's best-known work, Fahrenheit 451, published in 1953, became an instant classic in the era of McCarthyism for its exploration of themes of censorship and conformity. ## *Fahrenheit 451* and Book Burning

Bradbury's best-known work, Fahrenheit 451, published in 1953, became an instant classic in the era of McCarthyism for its exploration of themes of censorship and conformity. The novel's themes directly reflected concerns about book burning and censorship in the 1950s.

This practice, known as McCarthyism, is paralleled in Fahrenheit 451 through the government's strict laws against books, paranoia over secret groups hiding books, and the swift action of the Firemen to burn down homes suspected of housing secret caches of books.

## Personal Background and 1950s Context

Bradbury was born on August 22, 1920, in Waukegan, Illinois, to Esther (née Moberg) Bradbury (1888–1966), a Swedish immigrant, and Leonard Spaulding Bradbury (1890–1957), a power and telephone lineman of English ancestry.(no content)Ruled ineligible for military service by his local draft board because of his vision problems, Bradbury became a full-time writer by early 1943.

The 1950s were a crucial period for Bradbury's career and political awareness. Later that year, Bradbury's masterfully anti-consumerist but deeply libertarian novel, Fahrenheit 451, appeared, perhaps solidifying the author's anti-authoritarian reputation.
